docs.lead_paragraph: When two top names in health care formed an alliance in Massachusetts, it did not turn out well for consumers.
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts 1994 merger of Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women's Hospital into Partners Health Care system offers cautionary tale about risks of big hospital mergers; holds merger has given Partners enormous leverage to drive up prices and inhibit competition; says deal state's Atty Gen Martha Coakley struck with Partners only helps consumers temporarily; warns other states to proceed with caution, as mergers and their effects are hard to undo.
docs.snippet: When two top names in health care formed an alliance in Massachusetts, it did not turn out well for consumers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Standard G.D.P. doesn’t fully account for the role of government.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by public policy researcher Lew Daly notes many debates about role of government boil down to size of government compared to size of economy, as measured in gross domestic product; rejects such comparisons because GDP framework fails to note both public value in economy and fact that many government services are provided free; says by obscuring value of government, GDP framework is ignoring potentially crippling trade-offs between fiscal and regulatory austerity and public's needs.
docs.snippet: Standard G.D.P. doesn’t fully account for the role of government.

docs.lead_paragraph: Austria's plan to wipe out some Hypo Alpe Adria [HAABI.UL]creditors, despite guarantees from the nationalised bank's home province of Carinthia, could drive up borrowing costs for other state-backed firms, including utilities and health agencies.

headline.print_headline: Hypo Creditor Plan Casts Shadow Over Austrian Borrowers

docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign citizens now make up most of the clients at large surrogacy agencies in the United States, highlighting a divide between the country and much of the world over fundamental questions on family.

headline.seo: Foreign Couples Heading to America for Surrogate Pregnancies
headline.main: Coming to U.S. for Baby, and Womb to Carry It
headline.print_headline: Coming to U.S. for Baby, and Womb to Carry It

docs.abstract: United States is increasingly drawing affluent couples from around the world who wish to hire surrogate mothers; many large surrogacy agencies in US say international clients provide bulk of their business; traffic highlights divide between country and much of the world over fundamental questions about what constitutes a family, who is considered legal parent and whether paid childbirth is a service or exploitation (Series: Pregnancy For Pay).
docs.snippet: Foreign citizens now make up most of the clients at large surrogacy agencies in the United States, highlighting a divide between the country and much of the world over fundamental questions on family.
